properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall, with accumulations of 10 to 15 cm, is expected over southeastern Manitoba on Sunday. A low pressure system in the United States will spread an area of snow through the Dakotas and Minnesota tonight. Snow will reach southeastern Manitoba by Sunday morning, when heavy snow will begin over southeastern parts of the province. Snow will taper off late Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T13:24:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T21:25:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2171393555.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected Sunday morning. Freezing rain is expected to develop early Sunday morning. Temperatures will rise slightly above the freezing mark by Sunday afternoon, and the freezing rain is expected to transition to rain or possibly mixed with ice pellets. The freezing rain may persist in some areas where temperatures remain near the freezing mark. Ice accumulation of up to 10 mm is possible. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T12:42:58-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday and Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring heavy snow to areas of northwestern Ontario. There may also be drifting snow in some areas. Snow is expected to late Sunday morning and quickly intensify Sunday afternoon. The snow should become light Sunday night however it is expected to reintensify again Monday morning. The snow may be mixed with ice pellets at times Monday afternoon. On Sunday 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected. Additional amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible on Monday. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate late Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T12:48:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T20:49:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1462702431.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Major winter storm Sunday into Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring a significant mix of wintry precipitation to much of northern Ontario Sunday into Monday, including snow, ice pellets and freezing rain. Some areas may see rain as well. Significant ice accumulation may be possible and widespread power outages are expected where freezing rain is the primary form of precipitation. Additionally, strong easterly winds may accompany the precipitation, particularly on Monday. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T03:04:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T11:05:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1613636049.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice storm possible Sunday into Monday. Freezing rain is expected to develop Sunday morning or Sunday afternoon. The freezing rain may taper off briefly Sunday night but will redevelop early Monday and continue through the day. The freezing rain will finally transition to flurries Monday afternoon. Significant ice accumulation and widespread power outages are expected. Travel is expected to deteriorate Sunday morning. Travel conditions could be very poor on Monday. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm Monday. Occasional light snow or ice pellets are expected Sunday night. However, heavier precipitation is then forecast to arrive Monday morning and continue into Monday evening before transitioning to snow Monday night. There is considerable uncertainty as to the type of the heavier precipitation Monday. At this time freezing rain seems more likely, however there are some indications that ice pellets could be the primary type of precipitation. Travel is expected to be very poor Monday. If the precipitation falls mainly as freezing rain there is the potential for an ice storm, resulting in significant ice accumulation and widespread power outages. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T12:12:39-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, changing to rain, and strong winds expected New Year's Eve into New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total rainfall: 5 to 15 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 70 km/h, possibly higher. Locations: All of Prince Edward Island. Time span: Early Tuesday evening into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop early Tuesday evening ahead of this system and potentially become heavy at times before changing to rain after midnight then ending Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting up to 70 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening then diminish Wednesday morning. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact those travelling during the evening New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T11:46:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T19:47:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4078161914.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather expected Monday and Monday night ... An intense low pressure system will reach the Great Lakes on Monday and bring a mixture of snow, ice pellets and freezing rain over Southwestern Quebec. Snowfall amounts could approach 15 centimetres. Moreover, strong easterly winds could produce blowing snow locally. Precipitation could also fall as freezing rain at times Monday, especially over areas near the border of Ontario. As the exact track of this low could change, the types and amounts of precipitation could be subject to change. With this poor weather, road conditions should deteriorate. Consider the possibility of modifying non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T12:15:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T20:16:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0576180639.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and rain expected New Year's Eve into New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total rainfall: 5 to 20 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Locations: All of New Brunswick for snow, mainly southern New Brunswick for rain. Time span: early Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday morning, persisting into Wednesday afternoon over northern New Brunswick. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop Tuesday afternoon ahead of this system and spread to all of the province by early Tuesday evening. Snow will gradually change to rain over southern New Brunswick Tuesday night into Wednesday morning, but should persist as snow over northern sections well into Wednesday. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation could impact those travelling on New Year's Eve or New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T11:44:54-00:00

Locations: Iles de la Madeleine Time span: Late Tuesday evening into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop later Tuesday evening ahead of this system and potentially become heavy at times before changing to rain overnight then ending Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting up to 80 km/h or higher will develop later Tuesday evening then diminish near noon Wednesday. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact those travelling later in the evening New Year's Eve or early on New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and strong winds expected New Year's Eve into New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 2 to 10 cm, possibly higher over northern Nova Scotia. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h, possibly higher. Locations: All of Nova Scotia. Time span: Near noon Tuesday into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop near noon Tuesday over southwestern Nova Scotia ahead of this system and spread to all of the province by early Tuesday evening. Snow will change to rain during the afternoon over southwestern sections and elsewhere Tuesday evening. Strong southeast winds gusting up to 80 km/h or possibly higher will develop Tuesday afternoon and evening then diminish overnight. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation and strong winds could impact those travelling on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Snowfall Sunday and Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring heavy snow to a large portion of northwestern Ontario. There may also be drifting snow in some areas. Snow is expected to begin overnight and quickly intensify Sunday morning. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Sunday evening. Freezing drizzle may also be mixed with the snow at times Sunday afternoon. The snow should become light Sunday night, however, it is expected to reintensify again Monday morning, especially near Lake Superior. Additional amounts of 10 to 20 cm on Monday are possible for some communities. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected Sunday into Monday morning. Freezing rain or rain is expected to develop Sunday near noon or Sunday afternoon and continue through Sunday night into Monday morning. Temperatures are expected to remain near the freezing mark resulting in precipitation falling as freezing rain or rain. Temperatures are expected to rise above freezing near midday Monday changing any freezing rain into rain. Ice accumulation of 10 to 15 mm is possible. Travel is expected to be very poor Sunday into Monday, especially over higher terrain where colder temperatures will result in more ice build-up on untreated surfaces. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High southwestherly winds will lift the snow and cause blizzard conditions over this community beginning on Sunday evening. Weather conditions should improve Monday near midday. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T14:40:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T22:41:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2817027405.2019
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather expected on Monday... An intense low pressure system will reach the Great Lakes on Monday and bring a mixture of snow, ice pellets and freezing rain over Southwestern Quebec. Snowfall amounts could approach 15 centimetres. Moreover, strong easterly winds could produce blowing snow locally. Precipitation could also fall as freezing rain at times Monday, especially over areas near the border of Ontario. As the exact track of this low could change, the types and amounts of precipitation could be subject to change. With this poor weather, road conditions should deteriorate. Consider the possibility of modifying non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T08:21:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T16:22:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3974713908.2019
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area, Ville-Marie area, Témiscaming area, Dorval Lodge area, Le Domaine area, Rapides-des-Joachims area, Fort William - Shawville area, Mont-Laurier area, La Minerve - Rouge River area, Low - Wakefield area, Maniwaki - Gracefield area, Papineauville - Chénéville area, Papineau-Labelle Reserve area, Lièvre River area, Saint-Michel-des-Saints area, Saint-Donat - Mont-Tremblant Park area, Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Adèle - Saint-Sauveur area, Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Longueuil - Varennes area, Laval area, Montréal Island area, Châteauguay - La Prairie area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Saint-Rémi area, Valleyfield - Beauharnois area, Hemmingford area, Huntingdon area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Sorel - Yamaska area, Saint-Hyacinthe - Acton Vale area, Verchères - Beloeil area, Saint-Jean - Marieville area, Lacolle area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday and Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring heavy snow to areas of northwestern Ontario. There may also be drifting snow in some areas. Snow is expected to late Sunday morning and quickly intensify Sunday afternoon. The snow should become light Sunday night however it is expected to reintensify again Monday morning. The snow may be mixed with ice pellets at times Monday afternoon. On Sunday 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected. Additional amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible on Monday. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate late Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T08:32:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T16:33:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3878287030.2019
Area: Ignace - English River, Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid, Gull Bay - Black Sturgeon Lake, Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat, Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska will result in falling pressure over the Yukon. This will combine with higher pressure over the Northwest Territories to generate strong easterly winds today. The resulting blizzard conditions will affect almost the entire Dempster, including the Ogilvie Mountains. In addition, extreme wind chill values near minus 55 are expected. The blizzard conditions are expected to ease through this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T08:49:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T18:52:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3169354722.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Snow over the region will begin early Sunday morning and continue until the afternoon. There is also another snow event expected on Monday with further significant amounts in the 10 to 20 centimetre range. Travel is expected to become difficult in the Sunday morning to Sunday afternoon period. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T08:23:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T16:24:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3939971708.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds will reach up to 120 kilometres per hour beginning Sunday evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T14:40:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T22:41:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2249900316.2019
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill conditions near -55 will continue this evening. Overnight, temperatures are expected to moderate ending the warning conditions. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T13:23:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T22:31:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2819948380.2019
Area: Sachs Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Early morning temperatures near minus 38 degrees are expected. Falling surface pressures over the southern Yukon will generate increasing northeasterly winds today. As a result wind chill values will range from minus 50 to 55 this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T02:04:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T12:52:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4168778701.2019
Area: Old Crow

properties.Summary:

Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm Sunday into Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring a significant mix of wintry precipitation to much of northern Ontario Sunday into Monday, including snow, ice pellets and freezing rain. Some areas may see rain as well. Additionally, strong easterly winds may accompany the precipitation, particularly on Monday. Power outages are possible. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T12:52:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T20:53:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1864635746.2019
